"Give birth mothers the apology they deserve, so they can at least have some peace." @HumanRightsCtte

"I would very much welcome an apology to the birth mothers & fathers, to the adoptees, to the children of adoptees. I want an apology to carry the recognition of our trauma, our grief." @lizzieharvie tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@lizzieharvie outlines what should change
"1. Adoption agencies should listen to us - we are the experts
2. We should have access to our medical histories
3. All adoptees should be told that they are adopted
4. Adoptees should be supported to connect with their biological family

"Many of us adoptees suffer from some form of trauma which shows itself in various ways, yet the underlying theme of maternal separation, that we all share, is there." @lizzieharvie tells @HumanRightsCtte

"She has my eyes, my lips, and she has the same build as me. We are both silly, we find the same things funny. I met my birth father shortly after and discovered I am the oldest of 5 siblings" @lizzieharvie

"When I was 28 I met my birth mother. I can barely find the words to tell you what that felt like, seeing my birth mother in front of my own eyes after wondering my whole life what she would look like." @lizzieharvie tells @HumanRightsCtte

"The right to family life was simply not honoured. Many groups were in collusion with each other to carry out these forced adoptions. Adoption was offered up as the only remedy to avoid disgrace to your family" @lizzieharvie tells @HumanRightsCtte
"There is no adoption without loss. Every adopted child experiences trauma at the start of their life." @lizzieharvie tells @HumanRightsCtte

"I was around 16 when I saw my adoption records. I saw the name I was given at birth. It was like I was discovering a different person. Who was she? It was all a bit too much to take in." @lizzieharvie tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@lizzieharvie is now giving evidence of her experience as an adoptee. "Inside I felt a bit alone, I was always wondering what I'd done to be given up by my parents. As a child I thought I wasn't wanted" @HumanRightsCtte
"When the Australian Govt apologised, I could not believe how the mothers were being freed from their shame. I want to clear my name. I did not give him up." @AnnKeen11
What about the proposal for Govt to apologise for adoption practices? "I believe that only a Govt can apologise for society's attitude towards us at the time" @annkeen11 tells @HumanRightsCtte

"Where is my right to family life? My daughter's with another family. My family life has been totally disrupted. We could never talk about this afterwards. My brother viewed it as something very distasteful" Judy Baker tells @HumanRightsCtte

"Its been an enormous battle to regain my sense of self. To recognise that I deserve to have compassion for myself. To recognise that I am not and never was a bad person. To recognise that my motherhood should have been honoured and wasn't" Judy Baker says to @HumanRightsCtte

"This is 53 years later and here I am, a wreck, because of what happened to me and my daughter. I built a wall around myself, and it was only when my daughter found me 22 years ago, that that wall collapsed around me" Judy Baker tells @HumanRightsCtte

"And my parents came to see me and they were effusive, my dad said she was the most beautiful baby he'd ever seen. And it must have been awful for them to lose their first grandchild. But we all just wanted to do the right thing" @HumanRightsCtte
"They took me down into the labour ward, and I was just so concerned that she was going to be OK. I looked at her little face and I just fell in love." Judy Baker tells @HumanRightsCtte

"It had been drummed into me that the right thing would be to give my baby to somebody else to raise, because then she would never be called a bastard, her illegitimacy would be wiped out, she would never have stigma attached to her" @HumanRightsCtte
"When I went into labour, I thought I had indigestion, I didn't know what was going on. I knew I wasn't going to keep the baby, I was going to do 'the right thing'"

"I was sent to a Mother & Baby home. We had to sweep the staircase, with our big bellies, and cook the food. The cook would say 'come on you naughty girls', we all knew we were naughty. But all the inmates were in the same boat" Judy Baker tells @HumanRightsCtte

"I felt so sorry that I'd disappointed my mother, and she was just lovely to me. She wanted to protect me and do the best for me. And like me, she was coerced into believing the best thing would be to give up my baby" Judy Baker tells @HumanRightsCtte

"In 1967 I became pregnant. The thought of a backstreet abortion terrified me. I had an appointment at hospital, I saw a doctor & the hospital social worker, and she immediately mentioned adoption to me - at that very first moment of being in the system"

"Between 1950 and 1976, there were 484,000 adoptions. That's 484,000 mothers who lost their children. Its an inexcusable amount. Mothers who were forced by a system to give up our children" @HumanRightsCtte

Judy Baker is now telling the @HumanRightsCtte about her experience. "We all lost something through adoption. I lost my baby, my beloved child, who I nurtured for 7 weeks. My daughter lost me. We all start from a point of loss, but it isn't a loss you can grieve"

"I hope that at the end of the @HumanRightsCtte inquiry that we get some proper counselling that's specific for this. Because this is all a very specific emotion that needs addressing. I keep mine inside and busy myself to distract myself" @AnnKeen11

Did your experience affect your relationship with the rest of your family too? "Denial of my son by my parents hurt me. My siblings didn't know I'd had a baby until the 90s. I wanted to tell them. But there is still a barrier between me and my sibling" says @AnnKeen11

"Its impossible to get on with your life. And I know I'm not alone. I stand by thousands of women across the world who have lost their children. And then to be told "she gave him up". We should be able to clear our name on that. Because we didn't. @AnnKeen11

"You can't forget having a child. When I knew my son was going to be turning 6, I bought him a bike. But when I bought it, I knew I couldn't take it anywhere and I left it in a car park. But at least I knew I'd bought my son a bike" @AnnKeen11 tells @HumanRightsCtte
"Afterwards I was determined to be a nurse, and to make sure that everybody in my care received dignity and respect. And I believe I achieved that." @AnnKeen11

"For years after I felt worthless. When I was eventually reunited with my child, it was like something happened to my body, that got me back to being alive again. There was a feeling of numbness before that." @AnnKeen11 tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@AlfDubs asks, did nobody show you any kindness? "The social worker wasn't cruel to me, it was the structure around her which was about getting you to comply. If I'd been shown kindness I might have been able to say no I don't want this to happen" @AnnKeen11 says

"I had nobody to talk to. I did want to talk, but I was told nobody would respect me, nobody would care for me because of this wickedness. And you do believe it." @AnnKeen11 gives testimony to @HumanRightsCtte about the experience of unmarried mothers in the '50s, 60s & 70s
"And I was in a ward with other mothers, with their babies, with people bringing them flowers. I can't tell you how that was. And I was told "this is for the best" @AnnKeen11 tells @HumanRightsCtte

"I saw my son by chance. There was a midwife I thought had a kind face. I asked her. She was amazing, she let me see him, but she reminded me that my baby would be given away on the 10th day and that I shouldn't get too close." @HumanRightsCtte

"The lady doctor who stitched me, every time I moved slapped my leg and said keep still. It was just a horrific ordeal. At the end of labour, a mum gets rewarded with a child. But I didn't even get to see him. Just told no, no, no, this child is for adoption" @AnnKeen11

"When I went into labour, I was terrified, I wanted my mum. But I never expected it to be again another punishment, but the people caring for me in labour told me I couldn't have pain control because it would stop me from doing the same thing again"
"It is strange, but the only thing that was important for my family was to get me away, get it over with, and then return and everybody has been satisfied" @AnnKeen11 tells @HumanRightsCtte

"It was so awful for lots of us who were in Mother & Baby homes. And what was the crime we committed? That we were pregnant without being married" @AnnKeen11 tells @HumanRightsCtte about the experience of unmarried mothers in the 1950s, 60s & 70s

"I was sent away to a Mother and Baby home. I was told if you love this baby, you would want it to be cared for by someone else, because you're a bad girl. The only time I was allowed to love my baby was in our time before he was born."

"The man I was sent away to then abused me very badly, because nobody would believe me. He said he could abuse me because I was a wicked girl. I only told my mother 12 years ago about that man. I didn't think anyone would believe me" @HumanRightsCtte is told by @AnnKeen11

"My parents were trying to do their best to find a solution, but the only solution they could find was that the baby would be adopted. There was never any talk of termination. It was just despair really, my mother just wanted to put it right. So I was sent away" says @annkeen11

"Then when my dad found out, it was horrific. He said I'd let him down really badly and that I must be sent away, that no-one could find out about it." @AnnKeen11 tells @HumanRightsCtte. "I realised that I had really shamed my family"

The @HumanRightsCtte is hearing from birth mothers about their experience of adoption practices in the 1950s 60s & 70s.
"What was it like finding out you were pregnant in the 1950s?"
"It felt like fear. I was just terrified." @AnnKeen11 tells us

.@HumanRightsCtte will set record straight about what was done to unmarried mothers and their babies. Just wish we could turn back time. https://t.co/0oIGBoa0u4

"There were lifelong chaotic and catastrophic outcomes for women who experienced forced adoption. There cannot be a clearer example of trauma than a child being taken away from a caring mother & being told they were at fault for what happened" Prof Harold to @HumanRightsCtte

Was there consent in any sense as we would understand it? "Pre-1976, there was certainly no option for consent" says Prof Harold. "It was a forced decision with consent not ordinarily the option". @HumanRightsCtte

"Local authorities provided v little mother & baby accommodation, their main role was as financier for the homes and providing financial support for mothers to go through the adoption process. The legislation and financing provided by the state made it possible" @GrandCamouflage

"Adoption practice at local levels might have varied but it was all within the framework of what the state had provided" says @JitSandhu. @GrandCamouflage agrees that legislative framework created the sphere for practice. @HumanRightsCtte

"It was a very formal process of adoptions. It was the legislative framework that gave local authorities the power to arrange adoptions w/out having received a child into care. Adoption legislation was the key enabler of this process." @JitSandhu tells @HumanRightsCtte

"There's always cases of resistance and resilience but there's a risk in using them as examples, they are the exception not the rule. The rule was forced adoption." Prof Harold of @CamEdFac tells @HumanRightsCtte

"There was zero support. Complete and absolute denial. We can't underestimate just how cruel this was, the starting point was cruelty and not support and care". Prof Harold tells @HumanRightsCtte about adoptions in 50s, 60s and 70s.

"The starting point for unmarried pregnant women was 'we will withdraw support, you will be punished across this process'. Accounts of mothers not being provided w pain relief, being abused during childbirth, the child being extracted immediately after birth" Prof Harold says.
"But there is no one-size-fits-all for mother & baby homes. Often local communities were not even aware they were there." Prof Harold tells @HumanRightsCtte

"The scale cannot be underestimated in terms of how many young women were based in different structures, but they all had a fundamental function - to cloak presence of unmarried women, facilitate delivery of children, & placement of those children with 'acceptable' parents"

"Where would you start if you were a pregnant unmarried teenager? Who can you trust? The infrastructure was entirely constructed to remediate a problem, and the unmarried mother was seen as the bearer of that problem" Prof Harold of @CamEdFac tells @HumanRightsCtte
"There was no protest to the infrastructure in place at the time around forced adoptions. 'Shame' encapsulates lifelong experience of an unmarried mother." @HumanRightsCtte

"All local agencies would have pushed mothers towards moral agencies or adoption societies, invariably they were the ones who held the key as anyone asking for help was channelled to them" @GrandCamouflage tells @HumanRightsCtte

"We shouldn't underestimate the volumes of unmarried mothers that had only one option opened up to them, and that was adoption through the processes operating in this period" Prof Gordon Harold explains. @HumanRightsCtte

"The idea of choice is limiting, all the agencies and apparatus of the state were trying to compel women in this situation to choose the "right" option, which was adoption. All structures were pushing women down that route" Michael Lambert @GrandCamouflage tells @HumanRightsCtte
"If a pregnant unmarried mother opted for abortion before 1967, it would have been backstreet or self-induced, both which were illegal." @HumanRightsCtte
.@JitSandhu "During this period there was very little state support for single parents, so being able to support a child was unrealistic in practice. Levels of welfare were really restrictive"

"I was in deep shock that this process could happen to people I knew well. When numbers are seen, it gives a sense of how systematic this process was & couldn't have happened w/out contribution from professionals at all levels" Prof Harold of @CamEdFac tells @HumanRightsCtte

"I would say it was respectable working class people looking to avoid the stigma and shame associated w unmarried birth. It wasn't just the poorest, that would be too broad brush." @GrandCamouflage tells @HumanRightsCtte. "This issue of respectability is very important"

"There's evidence to say that women were often taken in middle of the night so no-one could see she was pregnant, & taken to mother & baby home outside the local area to save the family from the shame & stigma about it." @JitSandhu tells @HumanRightsCtte
.@JitSandhu "Often social workers recorded that women's parents had said its fine for you to come back home, but you are not allowed to bring that child". @HumanRightsCtte

Are there any common factors across circumstances in cases of adoption in 50s, 60s & 70s?
"The common factor is pregnant outside of marriage. Most were under 24. Significant number v young. Predominantly poorer families, with close religious affiliations" @HumanRightsCtte

Was it a case of the state wanting to establish 'normal family life' after the war? "The agencies empowered by the state were there to remove a child from an unmarried mother to place with parents deemed to be more socially acceptable" says Prof Gordon Harold. @HumanRightsCtte

On adoption during the 50s, 60s & 70s, Prof Gordon Harold says "these were not choices, these were forced impositions that deviate from any standard of human rights at the time, through to the change of adoption legislation" @HumanRightsCtte
It is estimated 250,000 women, half million children, experienced circumstances linked to mother and baby homes during the 50s, 60s & 70s, Prof Gordon Harold tells @HumanRightsCtte.
"For unmarried mothers in this period, it really was the social moral and cultural context which really drove their desire to relinquish their children for adoption" @HumanRightsCtte

"During the 1950s, 60s and 70s, adoption really was a means of controlling the illegitimate birth rates whilst also fulfilling the right for family life for those adoptive couples experiencing infertility issues" @JitSandhu tells @HumanRightsCtte at the beginning of the session
Leo Beckett was always at Margaret Beckett’s side, her enduring companion and biggest champion. What a loss. RIP

On Cart Judicial Reviews and proposed reforms in the Bill, "There is an anomaly here and I believe it is a targeted and common sense reform" @DominicRaab tells @HumanRightsCtte

Would the Judicial Review & Courts Bill deny the right to effective legal remedy enshrined under Art 13?
"No, if you look at the Bill & the balance considered on a quashing order, v clear that there is scope to avoid that. The consideration of redress is key consideration"

Why have previous attempts to change Human Rights Act have failed, and why do you think you'll be able to succeed?
"2015/16 we were overtaken by the referendum. Let's say I look forward to being the antidote to your cynicism" says @DominicRaab to @HumanRightsCtte

"We are bringing forwards a consultation precisely to provide the space to explore the implications of any proposals on the devolved legislatures. I look forward to working with all the administrations" @DominicRaab tells @HumanRightsCtte

Will @DominicRaab undertake to seek devolved legislatures consent before any change to the Human Rights Act? "I am mindful of the diff traditions of the UK and particularly in relation to Scotland" @HumanRightsCtte

So does @DominicRaab see himself being a champion of Human Rights across Gov?
"I see myself as a proud advocate of Human Rights, and of course that comes with my role. Inevitably decisions at the highest levels are triaged to cabinet committees" @HumanRightsCtte

How does @DominicRaab see his Human Rights role re: other Gov depts - will he police them?
"The law officers have primary role advising the Gov. I have a more overarching roles but I do think its important. I don't think we're under-lawyered in Gov" @HumanRightsCtte
"Because Strasbourg court does not operate a principle of precedent like a UK court, so a lot of caselaw has been quite haphazard, so I'm not sure the situation is binary." @HumanRightsCtte

Isn't it the case that being a party to ECHR, you accept the caselaw? How could we remain a party and disagree with it?
"Sec 2 of #HRAct only talks about a requirement to 'take into account' caselaw. There is no express obligation to follow caselaw." says @DominicRaab

But is it about scrutiny, or about decision making? Parlt decides on legislation, not Government. 
"Of course Parlt would have to make the decision. The law making prerogatives of Parlt are absolutely crucial" @DominicRaab tells @HumanRightsCtte

"You can either say Parlt. brings forwards legislation to correct anything it doesn't like, or you could look at a mechanism to do that in a specific way. But you would retain all of the due scrutiny. Let me reassure you we're not talking about shortcuts" @HumanRightsCtte
.@DominicRaab said in October that he was looking at legislation to allow Parlt. to correct court judgments. What is this new mechanism? @HumanRightsCtte

"Its not just a question of whether we are willing to sign up to a convention, but actually we are one of the strongest and most ardent advocates for human rights around the world and I'm proud of that tradition" @DominicRaab tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@joannaccherry notes that @DominicRaab would clearly like to see more emphasis on freedom of speech. But how does he justify clauses in the #PoliceBill? 
"Exercising freedoms shouldn't infringe other people's freedoms, I think we've struck right balance in #PoliceBill"

"My feeling is that most of those shifts ought to be decided by Parliament. There is more weight applied to liberty vis a vis freedom of speech, partly reflective of the civil law tradition on the continent" says @DominicRaab to @HumanRightsCtte

How is the Human Rights Act supposedly "at odds with the British tradition of liberty"?
"There is a question about extent to which privacy considerations under Art 8 have permeated our caselaw as a result of EU membership, but also as a result of Strasbourg caselaw"

.@DominicRaab says "My critique is never really about the ECHR, but the way it has been interpreted over time, the caselaw in particular, that is how the more continental civil law tradition has crept in" @HumanRightsCtte
If the flow is moving towards more restricted caselaw, would he not think that is a good thing? "I would see that as a good thing, but what ebbs may flow" says @DominicRaab to @HumanRightsCtte

.@DominicRaab says "the terrain has changed" since he drafted a Bill of Rights as an opposition MP. "There has been an ebb and flow between expansive caselaw and restricted caselaw since 2015" @HumanRightsCtte

Is @DominicRaab planning a British Bill of Rights?
"Allow me to announce it and set out the detail properly in front of the House of Commons in the right way" @HumanRightsCtte

.@DominicRaab declines to give much information on the Gov's planned overhaul to the Human Rights Act. 
"There has been debate about the procedural framework of the HRAct and how it is calibrated - separation of powers, retain judicial independence, protect democracy prerogative"

.@joannaccherry asks @DominicRaab about the comments by @VotePursglove in the Chamber. Can he clarify?
"The ECHR is often a lightning rod for criticism, but regarding what the Gov will be announcing I reaffirm my previous answer on our commitment to the ECHR" @HumanRightsCtte https://t.co/d4x5VNoBDJ

.@AlfDubs asks @DominicRaab if he believes Human Rights apply equally to everyone. "There are some qualified rights, the UK was right to insist we don't give prisoners the right to vote. Of course Human Rights as a general concept apply universally" 
@HumanRightsCtte

How will the Minister @DominicRaab ensure that the #NationalityandBordersBill doesn't breach the right to life? "I'm confident that the strategic objective of the Bill is crucial to protecting asylum seekers" @HumanRightsCtte

Can @DominicRaab give assurance that the UK will remain a party to the EU Convention on Human Rights? 
"Is the Gov committed to the UK remaining a state party to the ECHR? Yes" @HumanRightsCtte
He notes that it took me 10 years to ask him about his comments. If I had to police all the misogyny of Government Ministers all the time, I wouldn't have time to do anything else.

Lord Chancellor @DominicRaab called feminists "the most obnoxious bigots" - would he like to eat his words? He claims "I consider myself a proud champion of equality and my actions back that up" @HumanRightsCtte

Help people stay in their own countries, take our fair share of migrants, allow people to apply legally and don't do dangerous migrant boat 'pushback'. Me on BBC radio Kent 08:21👇 @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityandBordersBill  
https://t.co/jCcNZnis6U
.@VotePursglove "I am satisfied that we are proceeding in a manner entirely in keeping with our obligations".

A number of people have given evidence to @HumanRightsCtte that aspects of #NationalityandBordersBill breaches UK human rights obligations. The fact that they think that, will that enhance the UK's reputation as a global champion?
@joannaccherry points out that the Minister has not told the @HumanRightsCtte of a single new safe and legal route that the Gov proposes.

Do you think offshore processing at Nauru has enhanced Australia's reputation then?
"I consider that these matters are not in isolation. I would argue the approach we take is holistic, it is right to focus our effort on delivering safe and legal routes" says @VotePursglove

Will the #NationalityandBordersBill damage UK reputation as a champion for refugees and human rights?
"I think the inverse of that is true. If we continue to allow channel crossings will be hugely damaging to UK credibility" says Minister @VotePursglove

"The model we would be seeking to proceed with is one where individuals would be processed as part of the asylum system of the country we would collaborate with, rather than being processed as part of our system offshore" says @VotePursglove

"I'm not able to give a running commentary on negotiations with countries but we are very clear that we would only ever work with countries that are compliant with international human rights obligations" @VotePursglove to @HumanRightsCtte

@SarahLudford asks about offshore processing of asylum seekers. @MSF have told @HumanRightsCtte of terrible conditions of asylum seekers on Nauru. How will Gov guarantee human rights of asylum seekers are respected at all times?

Refugee convention makes clear that UK should not be criminalising those arriving irregularly. Why has Gov decided #NationalityandBordersBill is compatible with this? "Our purpose is not to penalise but to discourage people making dangerous journey to UK" @VotePursglove

Why has @ukhomeoffice not published advice on pull factors?
"We will the economic impact assessment in due course. It is very difficult to quantify complex pull factors. But there are some common themes." @VotePursglove tells @HumanRightsCtte

"But I would go back to point that all individuals getting in small boats are coming from safe France or safe Belgium. So there is no necessity to leave those countries to seek refuge." @VotePursglove tells @HumanRightsCtte

"It is important that cases are looked at on case-by-case basis. The system should be sympathetic in handling trauma and issues like mod slavery. When we operationalise #NationalityandBordersBill we need to think about that" @VotePursglove to @HumanRightsCtte

@dean4watford asks about pull factors. "I would argue there needs to be sensible control of our borders that has preserving life at its core, that also shows int. leadership" says @VotePursglove. @HumanRightsCtte

Has it been considered by @ukhomeoffice? And has it been suggested to the French?  
@VotePursglove commits to investigate and report back to @HumanRightsCtte.

One suggestion @HumanRightsCtte heard is to allow applications for asylum made from France. Will Gov not consider that?
"I do not want to see people making dangerous journeys wholesale. That suggestion just encourages people to make dangerous journeys to France" @VotePursglove

@joannaccherry asks: You seem to be saying that as far as the UK is concerned asylum seekers should just stay in first safe country? 
@VotePursglove says "nobody should be making dangerous journeys to UK and preservation of life is the fundamental principle" @HumanRightsCtte

@joannaccherry asks @VotePursglove "Doesn't your policy put unfair pressure on Italy and Greece? Why shouldn't it be shared across Europe?"
"I would argue very strongly that nobody needs to get into small boat in order to seek safety. It is an established principle and right."

"I'm forced to conclusion that the answer to the q what will the Gov do, is nothing much other than talking to the French" says @AlfDubs. 
"I would argue that cooperation with countries like France needs to be deepened in order to stop dangerous journeys" says @VotePursglove

"We are absolutely confident that provisions in Bill are compliant with international obligations. We want to stop dangerous journeys full stop. That's where collaboration with our neighbours is so important." @VotePursglove @HumanRightsCtte
@AlfDubs notes that the UNHCR has disputed the Gov's assertion about claiming asylum in the first safe country. What will the Gov do to stop people attempting riskier journeys?

"We do not want people making dangerous journeys in any context. Fundamental to our policy is longstanding approach, principle that people should claim asylum in first safe country they reach. I think that is of real importance." Minister @VotePursglove tells @HumanRightsCtte

3rd amendment ensures tactics don't endanger lives at sea. Will Gov look at that?
"It is for operational commanders at sea to take proper decisions, but I know that they are mindful of that issue". @HumanRightsCtte

Another amendment would ensure pushback isn't used against unseaworthy vessels. 
"I am confident that the operating model already takes proper account of that issue" says @VotePursglove to @HumanRightsCtte

.@HumanRightsCtte has drafted amendments to #NationalityandBordersBill. One ensures that tactics adhere to int. maritime law. Will Gov accept that?
"I am clear that we will always act in accordance with int. maritime law" @VotePursglove

It is reported that Gov knows pushback proposals are unworkable in practice. How are they going to work?
"We consider that those tactics are safe & legal. Is for commanders at sea to make decisions about deployment of those tactics" Minister @VotePursglove tells @HumanRightsCtte

"We do know there are 80m people displaced globally. Undoubtedly greater flows of people, not only do we need to deliver #NationalityandBordersBill, but we've got to continue providing help and support in areas of humanitarian crisis" says Minister @VotePursglove.

But why has there been such an increase in numbers?
"We are seeing criminal gangs actively identifying people who want to come here and providing a route. People are put under duress to cooperate with gangs. Greater risk being taken with people's lives." @HumanRightsCtte

Over 25,000 migrant arrivals in 2021. "Clearly Covid has affected available routes. We have also seen channel become route of choice rather than e.g. lorries. Criminal gangs have also become more daring." @VotePursglove tells @HumanRightsCtte

"The French authorities alerted us to that boat, at which point it was well within French territorial waters. We made all of our boats available. But it may be impossible to ever say with accuracy whether boat was in UK waters prior to that" @CCTCommander to @HumanRightsCtte

Did anyone in the boat that sank in the channel call the UK authorities? & what happened?
@CCTCommander tells @HumanRightsCtte "The UK received dozens of calls at that time and responded to all. I can't tell you whether we received a call from that specific boat"

"From my perspective safe and legal routes are absolutely crucial. We have done work with @Refugees  taking the most vulnerable people on the planet, that is something we continue to be mindful of with our policy." @HumanRightsCtte

What work is Gov doing to support safe routes for asylum?
"I think safe and legal routes are absolutely fundamental to policy. One of reasons I campaigned to leave EU was so we could have a fair immigration system that treats people equally." says @VotePursglove  @HumanRightsCtte

Does Gov feel any responsibility for 27 people who died in channel?
@ukhomeoffice Minister @VotePursglove says all the work he is doing is to stop criminals who traffic people across channel. What happened last week was a tragedy. @HumanRightsCtte

Is there a problem of adult asylum seekers falsely claiming to be children?
Luke Geoghegan from @BASW_UK explains that reality is that number of claims to be children are not upheld, because the system has a number of screens to stop this. @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityBordersBill

"Putting a rule that late evidence will receive less weight on statutory footing is interfering with the constitutional responsibility that judges have to make decision based on evidence in front of them. It is dangerous to put this in #NationalityBordersBill." @HumanRightsCtte

"Women who have been victims of FGM or sexual violence don't know that providing evidence may be part of their application. There are a huge number of scientifically documented reasons why people may not give all the evidence at once" @ZoeJardiniere tells @HumanRightsCtte

Lucy Moreton, Immigration Services Union says we have reached low point of faith in the system through many years of under-resourcing and neglect. #NationalityBordersBill isn't going to fix that. Will take as many years as took to break the system to make it work @HumanRightsCtte

"If the Home Sec says that they are economic migrants taking advantage, that's the perception the public will have, there will be a lack of trust in system and that political reality feeds upon itself." @ZoeJardiniere from @JCWI_UK at @HumanRightsCtte

.@ZoeJardiniere "The way that asylum seekers are spoken about do not reflect the reality. The perfect e.g. is the Home Secretary saying that those crossing the channel are not genuine asylum seekers. They are, they enter the asylum system and lodge an application"
What steps could be taken to develop an asylum system that would command public confidence, independent of numbers being accepted? @DSimmonds_RNP asks

"Nobody flees persecution carrying their documentation, but we do also have to have enough regard to individuals who would seek to exploit the protection of the UK" says Lucy Moreton of Immigration Services Union to @HumanRightsCtte

"When entire Gov policy seems to be led by intention to discredit and disbelieve and get rid of asylum seekers, I can't see a circumstance in which credible quality processes are put in place for those people who need our help." #NationalityBordersBill @HumanRightsCtte

"There is a problem of asylum seeking being politicised. This is a few 10s of '000s seeking safety in our country, it really shouldn't be front page news 8 months of the year." says @ZoeJardiniere of @JCWI_UK tells @HumanRightsCtte

"That's absurd, will complicate the system, will make it far more difficult for people genuinely fleeing persecution to obtain the protection they need. The #NationalityBordersBill will make the quality of decision making worse." @ZoeJardiniere of @JCWI_UK tells @HumanRightsCtte
E.g. a gay asylum seeker would have to both prove the reasonable likelihood they were beaten, AND prove on the balance of probability they were beaten because they are gay @HumanRightsCtte

"This will make it more complicated, with more challenges, but will mean that people who have faced horrifying situations will have to prove the same evidence at two different standards." @ZoeJardiniere @HumanRightsCtte

"There is significant evidence that that is not well understood, which is again a training issue. But the #NationalityBordersBill complicates and splits the standard of proof, requiring a higher standard in parts of the process"

@ZoeJardiniere tells @HumanRightsCtte "The standard of proof in asylum cases is deliberately set at a low level, because it is very serious issue to wrongfully deny somebody asylum who may struggle to provide documentary evidence of persecution."

Surely historic acceptance rates shouldn't be relevant when considering Human Rights of an individual?
Lucy Moreton agrees - says Civil Service falls down trying to apply productivity targets to an individual which can never improve quality of decision making @HumanRightsCtte

How can there be a "right" number of acceptance and refusal? Doesn't that remove the humanity of the process?
Lucy Moreton agrees it does remove the humanity from the process - whilst it is possible to set limits based on history, the practical application is difficult

Is there any algorithm monitoring caseworkers to see the rates of approval/denial of asylum claims? 
Lucy Moreton says the process is quality assured, decisions are double-checked, and they are checked for the right proportion of decisions. @HumanRightsCtte

"With the number of cases, timeframes are unrealistic. If we could resource better, and give staff the space to make a proper considered decision and take care of their own welfare, that would make a huge difference" @HumanRightsCtte

.@FloEshalomi asks Lucy Moreton of Immigration Services Union if caseworkers have raised concerns about their workload and wellbeing. "Very much so. The pressure being placed on staff to make decisions, means you can't do a job you are proud of and that affects them"

"We see people completely broken down who have become a shell, years later, asking when they will hear. And the #NationalityBordersBill will make this worse" says @ZoeJardiniere from @JCWI_UK to @HumanRightsCtte

"During that period, accommodation is substandard, we see mental health deteriorate, and in long term that is also detrimental to the country, their ability to integrate and start their lives again is hampered by this." @HumanRightsCtte

Asylum seekers are waiting on average over a year to hear about their application. This is a system that isn't working and its hard to tell where the blockage is. It causes huge detriment to mental health. @ZoeJardiniere tells @HumanRightsCtte #nationalitybordersbill

Resourcing, training, support & capacity to make sensible decisions in reasonable timeframe is most important for the case workers who make decisions on asylum, not independence from the Home Office - Lucy Moreton of Immigration Services Union @HumanRightsCtte

.@ZoeJardiniere: "We know there is a culture in the Home Office that appears to come from the top in terms of Ministers and Civil Service, trying to catch people out, catch people telling a lie, rather than taking pride that they are the dept. that could protect people"

On #NationalityBordersBill: "It will
- create greater delays in the asylum system
- increase likelihood of further appeals
- result in more people, genuinely fleeing persecution, being denied the protection that they need"
says @ZoeJardiniere to @HumanRightsCtte

"There is a real problem stemming from lack of support and resourcing within Home Office decision making. Everyday we see the impact of that on our clients, and we see it in the appeal figures, showing that decisions were made wrongly in first instance" says @ZoeJardiniere
"Home Office decision making is extremely unsatisfactory in asylum cases - this has been raised repeatedly in expert reports" @HumanRightsCtte hears from @ZoeJardiniere of @JCWI_UK

"The best way is to have a system that can quickly help the Gov to determine who is who, and then decide on the most appropriate solution for them. That is the crux of the system and where all efforts should be focused" Rossella Pagliuchi-Lor of @UNHCRUK tells @HumanRightsCtte

"How could UK deter unsafe migration, whilst still respecting those who are persecuted and respecting the rights of refugees?" @HumanRightsCtte 
"It would be impossible to entirely deter unsafe migration, simply because of the dynamics at work in the world such as climate change"

"In Australian context, no matter how strict and punitive the measures that have been introduced on people after they arrive, these have not correlated with a reduction in the overall numbers" @danghez tells @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityBordersBill
.@DanGhez says it is quite rare for liberal democracies to criminalise asylum in this way. Australia has never considered criminalising it in this way. @HumanRightsCtte
"A refugee cannot get a visa to claim asylum. The Bill is a wholesale attack in the non-penalisation provision in the Refugee Convention." @sonalinaikqc tells @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityBordersBill

Will making it an offence to arrive in the UK without permission reduce irregular entry to the UK? @sonalinaikqc says "the Bill will criminalise genuine asylum seekers, even if they have no option other than to flee" @HumanRightsCtte

"Being "in distress" does not require them to ask for help. The fact that they are in danger, that they have children and women on board, makes them in distress and in need. That's what guides our mission" @PonthieuAurelie tells @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityBordersBill

Why do @MSF recuse people at sea? @PonthieuAurelie "We rescue people at sea because we are a humanitarian organisation and we saw a very big gap in sea rescue so we started these operations. And any ship is bound by requirement to rescue any vessel in distress" @HumanRightsCtte

Vast majority of vessels carrying asylum seekers that would be intercepted would not be in condition to be safe left adrift at sea in another country's waters. @DanGhez tells @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityBordersBill

Would it be lawful for border force to direct a boat out of UK waters if there wasn't another country that was willing to accept the boat? 
@DanGhez says arguably there is a power to carry out a removal, but countries must still adhere to their search and rescue obligations.

"Any legislation that would legitimate or justify these practices would lead to very serious human rights consequences and the endangerment of lives"  @PonthieuAurelie tells @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityBordersBill
"We have witnessed physical violence, objects thrown at people in the middle of the sea. People have died during push backs, and we can testify to the endangerment that these practices create" @MSF

What happens when a vessel is subject to "push back"? @PonthieuAurelie from @MSF says that there is no safe way to push back a vessel at sea. The boats are filled with people already in danger and in immediate need of rescue. @HumanRightsCtte

"We've always upheld the principle in this country that however someone arrives on our shores we will give them a fair hearing & if they need protection we will grant it to them. That principle has been proudly upheld, and we should continue to recognise it." @HumanRightsCtte

.@EnverSol tells @HumanRightsCtte "We also need to recognise that many of those who come over the channel have legitimate need for humanitarian protection. Addressing it needs a more sophisticated response, including humanitarian visas, safe routes"

"The number of people seeking to come to this country cannot be solved by giving money to the French, it is a challenging issue for the whole Europe. There needs to be a proportionate political response to not overplay it & over-promise and under-deliver which damages trust"

How does #NationalityandBordersBill tackle small boats? @EnverSol "I recognise that this is a big political issue. We need to remember that the Gov can either make it more of a political issue, but the reality is that it is not possible to make that route unviable"

.@enversol tells the @HumanRightsCtte  "I would urge you to listen to the comments by the Independent Anti-Slavery Commissioner Dame Sarah Thornton about her concerns about the #NationalityandBordersBill." https://t.co/79qX0cp1ud

@M_Sumption from @MigObs tells @HumanRightsCtte "The tension in the #NationalityandBordersBill is that some of the mechanisms for deterring people from using certain routes of entry are also ones which would undermine later integration e.g. access to public funds."

"We should give people a fair hearing on UK soil. I am not convinced that this Bill will do anything to put people smugglers out of business or to stop people being exploited by smugglers" @EnverSol tells @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityandBordersBill

@EnverSol "The #NationalityandBordersBill works on the assumption that it is all about "pull" factors, if you create deterrent people won't come. But there is no evidence for that, and the Bill does nothing about the "push" factors, why people have to flee their countries"

"Legally the Bill just doesn't target the gangs. It criminalises & targets the victims of these people who are able to operate as they do because of the lack of safe legal routes. Practically every organisation involved in this agrees that" @RazaRazahusain tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@RazaRazahusain tells @HumanRightsCtte "The biggest reason you have gangs and people smugglers is because of the absence of safe legal routes. You don't tackle gangs by criminalising the victims of those gangs, but that's what the #NationalityandBordersBill does"

6. #NationalityandBordersBill provides no safe legal routes

7. Resettlement is a laudable aim but can't replace our asylum system. What happens in Afghanistan if you are number 5,001? Resettlement is complementary but not a substitute for the asylum system

5. Responsibility for receiving refugees was always intended to be a shared responsibility across nations. UNHCR recently said that requiring refugees to claim asylum in the first safe country would undermine the global humanitarian principles of refugee protection

4. #NationalityandBordersBill attacks the idea in the convention that refugees are entitled to some element of choice. There is no requirement to claim asylum in the first safe country you meet. That would be non-sensical.

3. Reason why the protection of illegal arrival is central to the convention is because the convention replaced previous regimes which permitted states to take refugees on pre-authorised basis only. Replaced it with a needs-based model. #NationalityandBordersBill reverses this

1. Non-penalisation of refugees who arrive irregularly is at the core of the Refugee Convention. 

2. We know that of those who arrive by routes outside of resettlement, 3/4 are granted asylum. So the attack on irregular arrival is empirically unfounded.

.@RazaRazahusain tells @HumanRightsCtte, he has 7 reasons for why the #NationalityandBordersBill is incompatible with the Refugee Convention and represents the biggest legal assault there has ever been on that convention.

"The longer people are left in refugee camps, the more it damages their health and wellbeing, their prospects, and their capacity to take their life forwards. We would argue for frontloading in the resettlement scheme with a clear timeframe" @EnverSol tells @HumanRightsCtte

Given the cap on the Afghan resettlement scheme is 5,000, have you made any estimates of how many might try to come to UK? @EnverSol "We haven't made any estimates.  In our view, 5,000 in first year is too limited, we think should be more in the first two years"

"We are very worried that under proposals in #NationalityandBordersBill Afghans will have the door slammed in their face, they could be criminalised, and if they get protection their rights will be limited" @EnverSol tells @HumanRightsCtte

"I would argue that the limitation of regular routes means that people don't have any other option, & taking that option is a legitimate option & is an option this country has always recognised. That principle is one we should uphold" @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityandBordersBill

How much choice to refugees have about how to enter the UK? @EnverSol "It's important to remember that the majority of the world's refugees don't come to UK and Europe; and the majority of those who do come here are granted refugee status" @HumanRightsCtte

Peter tells @HumanRightsCtte "The companies who are managing us in the hotels and emergency accommodations have no experience of health and wellbeing. I have to blame this on Government and the Home Office, the companies only care about making money" #NationalityandBordersBill

"I want to see a process where our career can be rejuvenated, where we can go back into the system so we can give back to the system, so that we can be a giver, instead of being dumped somewhere after being given that status of refugee." Ngozi tells @HumanRightsCtte
"I would like the accommodation for asylum seekers to be a place where humans can live, where you can be treated like a human being." @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityandBordersBill

...I would like to see a reform in the application process. The UK application process is too rigorous, it takes too long a time to go through the process. People's mental health is damaged in this process" @HumanRightsCtte

What changes does the UK asylum system need? Ngozi tells @HumanRightsCtte "I would like to see improvements in asylum accommodation; I would like to see the ban on right to work lifted for refugees and asylum seekers; I would like to see expanded family reunion law...
Elkhansaa tells a similar story. "The agent arranged the whole thing. Fortunately I came here on a flight. But you have no choice". #NationalityandBordersBill

Ngozi explains that her flight was direct from Heathrow. "I wish I knew that I had a choice, maybe I would have made a different choice. It is a very difficult thing for us to come all this way. I had no choice" @HumanRightsCtte

.@AlfDubs asks Peter if he went through any safe countries en route to the UK. "Yes I passed through 3 safe countries. But the smugglers had me with them the whole time, and they told me that if they left me I would be caught. I had no choice"
"Emotionally you have that sense of guilt, that you even left your own children because you don't have a choice. I've been lucky to land in the UK" @HumanRightsCtte #NationalityandBordersBill
"I didn't even know what asylum meant at the time and how it worked. I did my Masters degree in the UK and come for holidays, but this was totally different"

Elkhansaa of @VOICESNetworkUK tells @HumanRightsCtte that she has had to leave behind her husband and children for fear of her life. She came by plane. Her uncle paid for her flight, and a few weeks later he was killed by the authorities.
"All the way through, it was one hurdle to another, and living a life of not knowing what is next" @HumanRightsCtte

Ngozi, member of @VOICESNetworkUK tells @HumanRightsCtte that even if you pay for a solicitor, "it costs so much money to make an asylum application. Each refusal brings rejection and fear. When the approval came, we were only given 30 days to leave the place you call home."
"I never had the choice to stay in France, or anywhere else, so they [smugglers] would take me wherever they wanted without asking me." @HumanRightsCtte
"No, I was not aware of any other way to get from Iran to a safe country" Peter tells @HumanRightsCtte.

@joannaccherry asks Peter if he aware of any other routes of asylum to the UK? Peter says he never planned to come to the UK originally, and never knew he was going to spend 5 hours in a boat. His parents paid smugglers, who promised to take him somewhere safe.
Peter tells the @HumanRightsCtte how he was smuggled in a boat across the channel. He was in hiding in Iran because his life was in danger at the time, due to his conversion to Christianity.

Elkhansaa, from Sudan, explains "I left everything there, it was a question of being alive. We have ethnic persecution, I've been detained & tortured & threatened to be eliminated so I have to leave my country. I survived but I have no life, my life is on hold" @HumanRightsCtte

Ngozi, from Nigeria, explains that no-one wants to leave where they call home. "I enjoyed my days I loved my people, its not the same here. I was thinking of pursuing a PhD, but I had to forget that. But so long as I remain in the UK, I should be safe"

The @HumanRightsCtte is hearing evidence from refugees who have come to UK. Peter, from Iran, tells us that "compared to my home country I feel a lot safer here, but I'm am worried for my family" #NationalityandBordersBill

"I don't think its necessary to enshrine it in statute. I'm confident that we will see plenty of vigorous freedom of expression, the #PCSCBill is creating constistency" @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@HumanRightsCtte recommended that right to peaceful protest be set out in statute. Does @RobertBuckland agree? "I genuinely was puzzled by some of the noise and dissent about provisions in the #PCSCBill."

Should courts not be able to record youth court proceedings? @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte "I will certainly look carefully at the issue, I appreciate the seriousness of proceedings in youth courts"

"We don't have separation of powers constitution, we have checks & balances w/ independent elements playing vital role. If we accept that, it follows that whilst all of us operate w/in rule of law, it is ultimately a political principle as much as sovereignty of parlt."

@RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte: "I get dismayed by an idea of a 'them and us' situation, that Supreme Court occupies another world that means that 'naughty' parliaments can't do what they like. That is a really unhealthy way of looking at our constitution."

.@RobertBuckland says: "We're in trouble when we lose the independence of our judiciary. But any election is result of democratic elections, and we shouldn't be hesitant of politicians saying we're an important part of the constitution, that works with an independent judiciary."

"I make no apology for wanting to return things to a more balanced position, than one that was I think undermined by some of the legislation of the previous Labour Govt." @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

"I'm not after revolution, I believe in incrementalism. Really what I'm seeking is to return things to the position that we were in the mid- to late-20th century re: the relationship between the judiciary and other parts of the constitution" @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

@joannaccherry asks if @RobertBuckland can give example of where the rule of law has been implemented in political way. "I can think of cases where there is tension w/in court, judges are put in position where their own moral view becomes important. That becomes political"

"There is a danger that we elevate the political principle rule of law in a way that can cause unnecessary tension by juxtaposing it against parliamentary sovereignty" @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

"That worries me. The rule of law is hugely important but is a political construct, and is different to the law itself. I seek to make the argument for a happy balance of compatibility between political principle of rule of law, and sovereignty of parlt." @RobertBuckland

"We're in position where the rule of law and parliamentary sovereignty are juxtaposed as if two different philosophies. I think that overall perception that Miller 2 created was a war between world of rule of law and world of Govt." @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

"I don't think there is difference between us on fundamental importance of Judicial Review. What is important is to make sure that balance is as perfectly maintained as possible, avoid position when courts are brought into political arena" @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@joannaccherry asks @RobertBuckland: "If Govt. breaches the law laid down by Parlt, Judicial Review allows them to be held to account. Isn't it right that courts can comply Govt. to comply w/ will of Parlt.?"

"I was very keen to make sure that the full spectrum of opinion and perception on both sides of Irish border were reflected, and I'm confident that we'll see that when report is published." @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@joannaccherry asks @RobertBuckland: "It was concerning to hear about possible impact of reforming #HRAct on Good Friday Agreement. Has Govt. taken account of this risk in their plans for reform?" @HumanRightsCtte

.@RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte: "Speaking personally, the possibility that Courts could strike down a UK Statutory Instrument [for human rights compliance], is less of an issue for me than some of the other matters we've discussed"

"I do not think the sovereignty of parliament is undermined by the #HRAct, but there are times when the space in which the Courts have to inhabit can be a very tricky one indeed" @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

Does #HRAct protect parliamentary sovereignty? @RobertBuckland says "It is the responsibility of the legislators to get it right & make law clear so that European courts aren't put into a position where they have to interpret things that cld be deemed political" @HumanRightsCtte
"Whilst there is always room for reform, fundamentally the European Convention on Human Rights is a very fine document" Lord Chancellor @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@RobertBuckland says he was thought that evidence given to the @HumanRightsCtte seemed to be one-sided. But voices we heard from were:
- voices of the judiciary
- voices of the police
- voices of people who were actually working within the #HRAct.  We didn't choose what they say
"For all sorts of legitimate reasons, it is right at this stage for the review to look at the framework of the #HRAct" @RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte

"Whilst #HRAct is an elegantly drafted piece of work, it was the result of political decisions taken at the time. E.g. balance of freedom of expression and privacy, one example of how domestic politics came into play in drafting of the #HRAct" @HumanRightsCtte

.@RobertBuckland tells @HumanRightsCtte "It is right and timely to look at that Act and how it can be updated. There are differing views about the efficacy of the #HRAct. It is my job to make sure that the Act is working as well as it can"
The @HumanRightsCtte is taking evidence from Lord Chancellor @RobertBuckland. First question is, why does he think it is necessary to review the #HumanRightsAct?

"There is something powerful about enshrining into law something we believe is important. I think incorporation into law would also be good for our standing internationally." Claudia Sturt @_YJB @HumanRightsCtte

.@hazelwil43 of @AssnYOTmanagers "Enshrining this in UK law would give us more strings to our bow, to argue more that we need to do things in the best interests of children. So absolutely why wouldn't we" @HumanRightsCtte

"The @_YJB isn't able to support the proposed sentencing changes for children in #PCSCBill. The purpose of sentencing adults and children are not the same. With children sentencing is about prevention of offending and welfare of child." Claudia Sturt tells @HumanRightsCtte

"There's something about how the whole justice system learns how to do victim work really well, so that it supports victims. Its often better for victims to work with a specialist and receive some kind of restoration" @hazelwil43 tells @HumanRightsCtte

"I feel very strongly that removing opportunities for review for tariff lengths is not a solution to dealing with the grief and distress of bereaved families" Claudia Sturt of @_YJB tells @HumanRightsCtte #PCSCBill

"The longer people have on license the better chance they have to integrate into community. If people have support and have those support systems around them, that will stop them from reoffending in future." @hazelwil43 of @AssnYOTmanagers tells @HumanRightsCtte

"If we are going to have a taper for tariffs for children, and I'd like to see a taper, but that taper should be between the ages of 18 and 25, not below the age of 18" Claudia Sturt of @_YJB tells @HumanRightsCtte #PCSCBill
"The #PCSCBill could be improved by offering an explanation of what could constitute an exceptional circumstance in youth sentencing and minimum terms" @HumanRightsCtte

"Minimum terms are directly at odds with treating each case individually, it would be hard to see how more children will not suffer increased time in custody as a result" Claudia Sturt of @_YJB tells @HumanRightsCtte
"The idea of sentencing more heavily to emphasise the seriousness of an offence is not compatible with a child-first principle" Clauda Sturt of @_YJB tells @HumanRightsCtte

"We're an evidence-based body & evidence shows that treating children as children is the most way to achieve reduced offending. Concerns with #PCSCBill Part 7 is that it blurs line between child and adult, and we question evidence base for it" Claudia Sturt tells @HumanRightsCtte

Would having records of evidence and deliberations improve accountability? Claudia Sturt of @_YJB "I was astonished to hear that they are not currently recorded. If reasons for decisions are not being recorded, there is a real issue of fairness". @HumanRightsCtte

Should UN Convention on the Rights of the Child be incorporated into UK law? "It would be a really important & welcome development, creating mechanisms for the state to be held to account" @pgoodfellow_ of @the_AYJ tells @HumanRightsCtte. "It would send a really positive message"

.@LauraJanes_UK adds that the race discrimination issue in remand is massive - "If we want to sort out the racism in the system then we need to sort out remand. The #PCSCBill proposals are welcome but must be the beginning of the story, not the end". @HumanRightsCtte

.@pgoodfellow_ of @the_AYJ tells @HumanRightsCtte that the changes to remand in #PCSCBill are welcome, but don't go far enough. "It is a welcome development because of the extent of the issue that we are facing, but that could further."

Are there human rights concerns about the #PCSCBill proposal to extend whole life orders? "To take away from a young adult the right to hope and right to change, yes there are particular concerns about a breach of Art. 3 Human Rights Act" @LauraJanes_UK tells @HumanRightsCtte

"Lots of children will find that they lose lots of the personal, social and emotional support and when they come out they won't have the scaffold social care support, which isn't good for the children and isn't good for anybody." @HumanRightsCtte

Is increasing the time the most serious child offenders spend in prison inconsistent with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child? "Yes absolutely, it seems entirely incompatible" @LauraJanes_UK tells @HumanRightsCtte

"There is no evidence that the current provision isn't working. It is a very concerning provision, it absolutely impinges on rights, and there is no evidence it is actually going to help. No evidence that prison sentences affect knife crime" @LauraJanes_UK of @TheHowardLeague

The #PoliceBill would require courts to impose minimum sentences. @LauraJanes_UK says that "this provision aims to restrict judicial discretion. That is inherently incompatible with the "best interests" principle re: children, you shouldn't be restricted" @HumanRightsCtte

.@daniellejmanson explains to the @HumanRightsCtte that youth courts are not courts of record - the proceedings are not recorded and available as evidence of fact. "It creates huge issues". The #PoliceBill is an opportunity to address these issues.

"Almost 1/2 of children in custody are from BAME communities. Anything that increases proportion of children in custody is going to affect BAME children. This #PoliceBill will increase no. of children and length of time" @LauraJanes_UK of @TheHowardLeague tells @HumanRightsCtte

"They're actually going to exacerbate inequalities and make them worse. I think it might be framed in a way to suggest that harsher punishments is what justice is, but justice is about everyone being treated fairly". @daniellejmanson tells @HumanRightsCtte

The @HumanRightsCtte is hearing evidence on the Govt's #PoliceBill. 

"The justification that the aim of the #PoliceBill is to ensure that justice has been done needs to be unpicked, because in my opinion justice is fairness and equality in the law" says @daniellejmanson.

The @HumanRightsCtte asks Lord Faulks about the Human Rights Act Review "I don't understand that there is any suggestion of radical change to HR Act. We're not going to be repealing it, there won't be an amendment to convention rights. But will wait and see what Govt does"

"There is a question about funding of judicial reviews. One of points of report of Independent Review of Administrative Law is that we think there should be clarification around crowd funding, it requires regulation. Its a balance that has to be struck" @HumanRightsCtte
"The use or possible abuse of judicial review is a genuine concern for Govt. There are groups that use jr as weapon of choice".

Lord Faulks: The current framework tries to balance. "Although its right that people should be able to enforce their human rights, its also right that Gov should be able to carry out policies and not be endlessly judicially reviewed regardless of merits."

The @HumanRightsCtte noted that the risk of an adverse costs order requiring claimant to pay opponents’ legal fees dissuaded public interest claimants from accessing judicial review & enforcing human rights. Do you think  claimants should be better protected from these costs?

"Any decision to do something about Judicial Review, radically, we think would be wrong and potentially contrary to the rule of law". Lord Faulks QC, Chair of the Independent Review of Administrative Law, tells @HumanRightsCtte

But the fact that one might not agree with a particular decision does not indicate something wrong with Judicial Review overall. Despite having a number of cases drawn to our attention, we did not think anything so wrong with JR that we should start again @HumanRightsCtte
But, we absolutely accepted that it was perfectly in order for Parliament to decide to reverse a particular court decision. That is Parlt. sovereignty.

Why did Independent Review of Admin. Law determine there was no case for radical reform of Judicial Review? Lord Faulks: We came to conclusion that legislation would not help, that overall way that JR works is satisfactory @HumanRightsCtte

Lord Faulks QC, Chair of Independent Review of Administrative Law, outlines how Judicial Review is judiciary making sure that the Gov abides by the decisions of Parliament, not judiciary vs. executive. Judiciary ensuring that will of Parliament is followed 
@HumanRightsCtte

Lord Faulks QC starts the @HumanRightsCtte hearing: "The role of Judicial Review is extremely important. The judiciary provides an important safety valve to prevent the executive from overreaching or acting in such a way that it unlawful"

"There were limitations to the voter ID pilots. But pilots told us there was definite potential for disproportionate impact, and further research has given clear picture of potential impact - unemployed, young people, disabled people all less likely to have ID" @HumanRightsCtte

How does @ElectoralCommUK feel about fact that system discriminates about black people to vote? Bob Posner CEO says: we've invested a lot of time on this, we'd be delighted if a real effort was made to improve the registration system. @HumanRightsCtte

"We think introducing automatic voter registration would be completely realistic and feasible based on infrastructure currently in place in the UK, and that would have a real benefit in picking up people not registered." @PhilGThompson of @ElectoralCommUK tells @HumanRightsCtte

What is @ElectoralCommUK est. of how many people are entitled but have not reg. to vote? @PhilGThompson says we think 83% are correctly registered meaning 8-9million people were not on electoral register at their residence @HumanRightsCtte

"We've seen that there is a particular pattern of people who are less likely to have ID but they are different to groups who are less likely to vote. Theres both factual, and behavioural aspect to voting. Those two aspects are really important to @ElectoralCommUK @HumanRightsCtte
"Absolute accessibility is one of our key planks, I can assure you" Bob Posner of @ElectoralCommUK tells @HumanRightsCtte when asked about stance on voter ID.

Bob Posner @ElectoralCommUK: What we've said is there is a vulnerability in the system, but have set up three tests for any change to system. We have not suggested that #ElectoralIntegrityBill has passed those tests, we await to legislation. @HumanRightsCtte

Legitimacy might be undermined by fears of electoral fraud, but there is also q of legitimacy undermined by obstacles to participation. Is @ElectoralCommUK pandering to unreal concerns, going along with baseless concern as a pretext to make system more exclusive? @HumanRightsCtte

Are there other electoral issues that should be priority in sorting? Bob Posner @ElectoralCommUK: If you asked me what should come first, our electoral law system is archaic and could do with an overhaul. Modernising the framework of electoral law is v impt. @HumanRightsCtte

Bob Posner @ElectoralCommUK continues: "It is also about confidence in our system and legitimacy of election results. We do know that many people are very concerned that there is fraud going on in our electoral system, including at polling stations" @HumanRightsCtte

@joannaccherry asks, surely we have to look at the evidence and carry out a cost-benefit anal? Does the balance not favour status quo? Bob Posner @ElectoralCommUK I'm not suggesting there is high incidence of impersonation, but we can't say there definitely isn't.

Why have @ElectoralCommUK recommended voter ID in UK? Bob Posner, CEO: Our position is that it isn't acceptable to ignore the vulnerability of polling stations, but in doing so it is important to balance accessibility for all. We await publication of the #ElectoralIntegrityBill

Should non-photo forms of ID be accptable? Lord Woolley: If youre reluctant to vote, its just another layer. If you had blank sheet, youd put more energy in political education, and make it easier and not more restrictive. That is opposite to what we're doing" @HumanRightsCtte
"27% of those without any form of ID said the requirement would make them less likely to vote. So we're getting a picture of a potential chilling effect that voter ID could have." @HumanRightsCtte

.@JessicaJGarland: "During the pilots, 2% of people said they didn't turn up to vote because of the ID requirements. Yes its small but that's still very damaging and completely out of proportion to instances of fraud" @HumanRightsCtte #ElectoralIntegrityBill

"I am tired in my 30 years of activism of communities saying to me 'it makes no difference' even though you know and I know that elections are won and lost in the margins. If they don't feel empowered, we can register them but they still won't go to the polls" @OpBlackVote

Could automatic voter registration mitigate effects of voter ID requirement? Lord Woolley @OpBlackVote: "I wholeheartedly agree with automatic voter registration, but its not a silver bullet. You still wouldn't get everybody to the polls, that requires citizenship education"

"Gov research on access to ID also shows low uptake by those unemployed and those with fewer qualifications, so there is clearly an economic and educational aspect to this too" - Prof @TobySJames adds to Lord Woolley's evidence @HumanRightsCtte

Voter ID will affect right across the board. Not just BAME communities, but the elderly, those in temp accommodation, young people, there is a plethora of people that will be affected - Lord Woolley from @OpBlackVote tells @HumanRightsCtte

Some people argue that voter ID proposals work in Northern Ireland. "We haven't had a really thorough study to my knowledge. We shouldn't be too quick to assume that everything has worked perfectly in NI" Prof @TobySJames tells @HumanRightsCtte
"We would have to expect a monstruous drop off of people engaging in the democratic process if voter ID proposals go ahead" Lord Woolley of @OpBlackVote tells @HumanRightsCtte

"If we want a robust democracy then we should be asking what is the nature of our citizenship education. Not just in schools but in communities too. There are huge swathes of our public not engaging in the most impt civic role that we can play" Lord Woolley tells @HumanRightsCtte
There are real questions about whether the requirement for voter ID would be in line with the 2010 Equality Act - Prof @TobySJames tells @HumanRightsCtte

Prof @TobySJames of @uniofeastanglia explains how during the voting ID pilots, some people even didn't vote because they philosophically declined to provide ID, not because of lack of ID @HumanRightsCtte

"Part of this mistrust is real - we've seen it with vaccinations, mistrust in the Govt., mistrust in institutions, that has cost lives. This hesitancy is extremely real" Lord Woolley tells @HumanRightsCtte

Lord Woolley of @OpBlackVote: What I'm deeply afraid of is if there is another layer of bureacracy, it is another impediment to a group who are already hesitant to fully engage with the democratic process. @HumanRightsCtte

@JessicaJGarland Cabinet Office research suggests 9% of people don't have in-date recognisable ID, and 4% don't even have out-of-date recognisable ID. That could mean millions do not have requisite ID and would be unable to vote @HumanRightsCtte

The UK doesn't require citizens to carry ID cards. How would this complicate voter ID requirements? @JessicaJGarland: It complicates it quite significantly. The cost aspect of ID is particularly worrying, ability to pay is not equal and suggests particular groups will be affected
Lord Wooley of @OpBlackVote "As outlined, it is implausible and the evidence clearly shows that there isn't any scale of fraud that we can see". @HumanRightsCtte

.@JessicaJGarland "I agree. Lots of people would have to be involved, you'd have to know who is not going to vote, the candidate would have to be aware, we're talking about a large scale operation and I think it is implausible to believe that could be undetected" @HumanRightsCtte
