"If #PCSCBill is enacted we will look at how we enforce it, but we will need a lot of clarification that we hope the Home Secretary @pritipatel will provide. But it has always been @PoliceChiefs position that we do not seek further legislation" @jem7069 to @HumanRightsCtte

@jem7069 from @PoliceChiefs answers: "We will enforce the law as it is. But we've always been very clear that issue of unauthorised encampments has been  issue of planning and accommodation. No the police are not seeking any additional legislation to deal with that issue."

A Freedom Of Information request found that only 21% of police bodies agreed with Home Office proposals to criminalise unauthorised encampments. Is that a fair reflection of police's view? @HumanRightsCtte
"What is a planning and accommodation issue has now become a policing issue and a criminalisation issue." @HumanRightsCtte

"The reality for officers on the ground, where there is no provision for Travellers, they are in a difficult position trying to balance the tensions between Travellers and settler communities." @jem7069 to @HumanRightsCtte

"We understand there is tension between Traveller and settler community and officers are in the middle of that. We provide officers with operational guidance, being clear that legislation is there but should be used in a proportionate way.

Janette McCormick, National Police Chiefs' Council @jem7069, explains "Our officers are often in an unenviable position. You have unauthorised encampment, families looking for somewhere to stay, and using existing legislation would just push them down the road elsewhere."

"There is still a pattern of travelling that is happening from people that have a settled base somewhere. So even if you had enough provision for everybody, you wouldn't eliminate travelling. Some is for economic, some for social purposes, some for holiday" @HumanRightsCtte

Second panel of today's @HumanRightsCtte. Bill Forrester, Chair National Assoc of Gypsy & Traveller Officers, explains that there is a certain level of travelling that is happening even when there is greater % provision of sites.

.@GallagherGRT "It was as bad as propaganda from World War 2, essentially criminalising and dehumanising us. To pander to the people that don't want us to have human rights. For him to call essentially for ethnic cleansing and forced assimilation was a disappointment"

Philomena from @LondonGypsyTrav agrees. "I was disgusted. How dare he criminalise a whole community. He should walk in our shoes and see what life is for us, we are good people. I was highly offended." @HumanRightsCtte

.@joannaccherry turns to Matthew Parris' article. @mwillersqc says "It was  badly researched, no attempt to engage with Gypsies and Travellers and understand their perspective. There was faux concern but forcible assimilation was focus of article and was abhorrent in my opinion"

"Giving police the power to seize someone's home amounts to a disproportionate response to a situation which arises primarily because of a failure on part of local authorities and Gov to meet the accommodation need of Gypsies and Travellers" @mwillersqc to @HumanRightsCtte
"I do think there will be wholesale challenge to the #PCSCBill on the basis that it breaches Articles 3, 8, and 14 of the Human Rights Act." @mwillersqc explains to @HumanRightsCtte

"The idea you can be criminalised because an owner  occupier has a concern that occupation of land will cause them significant distress, because occupiers are *likely* to take certain action, panders to tropes propagated in media by people like Matthew Parris" @HumanRightsCtte

"The definitions used in #PCSCBill on unauthorised encampments are very vague and offend the principle of certainty in criminal offences. What constitutes "significant disruption"? It is all very ambiguous." @mwillersqc tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@bowers_jake tells story of support w/in community for young woman going to hospital. "Last week 120 members of her family came together. That's why people need sites. It is insane this is coming from the Conservative Party that says it supports family values." @HumanRightsCtte

"The litmus test of a democratic society is how you treat the Gypsy, Roma and Traveller population - we should be doing more, we can do better, and the #PCSCBill is abhorrent in my professional opinion." @mwillersqc tells @HumanRightsCtte

"The vast majority of police forces say that it isn't new powers that are needed, what is needed is more sites for Gypsies & Travellers - temporary, transit and permanent." @mwillersqc tells @HumanRightsCtte

What protections are their currently for the GRT community? @mwillersqc "If a decision is taken to direct them to leave, they would find it v difficult to not comply. Most comply w/ requirements to leave."

@mwillersqc tells @HumanRightsCtte that #PCSCBill  will force Gypsies & Travellers into a position where they can no longer exercise their traditional way of life, and will be subject to even greater speed of eviction from places where they stop.
The #PCSCBill will take away our rights, threatening us and criminalising our way of life. It is a dangerous pre-cursor to what might come. @GallagherGRT  to @HumanRightsCtte

.@GallagherGRT: the biggest issue is the availability of sites, there are no sites and the planning process is unfairly stacked against GRT people from building their own accommodation. Nobody is fighting for unauthorised encampments, we want safe places to stay"
Philomena Mongan from @LondonGypsyTrav explains: "Its been 20 years since any caravan site has been built in London. There's no stopping places and no transit sites." @HumanRightsCtte
"We are the canary in the coal mine of liberty. If our life and our culture gets stamped out, everyone else's is one step behind". @bowers_jake tells @HumanRightsCtte

Are #PCSCBill changes needed? @bowers_jake: "There are more than enough powers to chase and harass people, there is no legal duty to provide sites for people. To say we need to increase police powers further is a damning indictment of this country." @HumanRightsCtte

What are the provisions in the #PCSCBill motivated by? @bowers_jake: "If I'm honest, I think it is motivated by racial hatred. That's where it is coming from. It is performative prejudice, a prejudice that can still be got away with." @HumanRightsCtte

.@mwillersqc adds that although there appears to be positive approach by Scot Gov engaging with Gypsies & Travellers, there is not much of a developed legal basis for Gypsies & Travellers to work with in Scotland. @HumanRightsCtte

.@joannaccherry asks about the situation in Scotland. @bowers_jake explains that the Scot Gov is much more human in way that it treats Gypsy & Traveller community. By no means perfect, but attitudes in Scotland better than in England. @HumanRightsCtte
"There are 0 transit sites in Wales. With the #Policebill we will face a situation where Gypsy, Roma and Travellers have even less protection and human rights." @GallagherGRT tells @HumanRightsCtte

"Since the closure of the commons, local authorities have been failing to meet the accommodation needs of Gypsies and Travellers. We have a never ending cycle of those who have nowhere to lawfully station their caravans, being moved around on a road to nowhere" @HumanRightsCtte

.@mwillersqc "I would conclusively say that public authorities are not meeting the obligation to facilitate the Gypsy way of life. The #Policebill will hit hardest those who wish to continue with their traditional way of life.

Philomena Mongan from @LondonGypsyTrav tells @HumanRightsCtte "I've been refused entry to pubs, cafes, parks, my kids have been turned away from sports clubs, made to feel ashamed. It is a struggle to be a Traveller or Gypsy in London. Something has to change"

"What is upsetting from a human rights perspective is that in 2021 we are still having to defend our right to a nomadic way of life. We're proud of who we are, we're not going anywhere, we've had a hard time, and we would like it to get better" @bowers_jake to @HumanRightsCtte

"Some communities I meet with are evicted two or three times a day, their caravans are firebombed, they are treated with suspicion and any attempt we make to change that is pushed back on by the right wing media. And that situation is about to get worse" #Policebill

What is it like to be a member of the Gypsy, Roma and Traveller community in 2021? 
"We still have some way to go before we are accepted as much as we are in countries like Sweden. In Britain we live in the cracks between communities" @bowers_jake tells the @HumanRightsCtte

Matt Parr of @HMICFRS agrees "I don't think it is an attack on the right to protest, far from it. I don't think it will have a chilling effect". @HumanRightsCtte
"We think it provides clarity, consistency, and gives policing the ability for preventative measures to deal with those who would cause a public nuisance" @BJH251 tells the @HumanRightsCtte

Chief Constable @BJH251 to @HumanRightsCtte "We do welcome the clarity of a new statutory offence of public nuisance. We do sometimes see orgs or groups who would set out to cause public nuisance, by making it a stat offence gives police ability to take preventative action"

Matt Parr of @HMICFRS : "We did support this proposal. On balance we thought this was OK. Although we didn't specifically advocate for use of word "unease" or ask for noise to be included." @HumanRightsCtte

Could "unease" not be interpreted very widely? E.g. bystander not liking the cause being championed? Chief Constable @BJH251 explains that the wording and phraseology is a matter for parlt. & police will interpret in line with relevant guidance @HumanRightsCtte

What conduct is covered by new noise trigger in Police Bill that isn't already covered by Public Order Act? Chief Constable @BJH251"We think there is a need for a lower threshold for disruption, and to do so in a way that is clear for policing and those impacted" @HumanRightsCtte

Matt Parr of @HMICFRS "That is correct, there was widespread support within the community. But the justification for not letting the #SarahEverard vigil go ahead were about covid restrictions, not disruption to the community" @HumanRightsCtte

But what about #SarahEverard vigil? If you'd asked community of Clapham Common they would have been supportive. Was there any consultation with actual local community? @BJH251 "Hard for me to say as I wasn't involved, but I am aware local police were engaged with community"

In relation to serious disruption to life of the community, do you consult the community or do you make an assumption? Chief Constable @BJH251 "No assumptions are made. Are we able to identify affected communities? Sometimes not."

Chief Constable @BJH251: "It is in terms of assemblies where we believe there is a need for greater consistency with Sec 12 of Public Order Act, that is what we are asking for. But with processions, we think those powers are proper." @HumanRightsCtte

"Police will look at the group's history, ask to meet with organisers, sometimes engaging with other groups or counter-protest groups. We recognise the fundamental rights and we believe they are important. Then we ask how to best discharge rights @BJH251 tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@joannaccherry asks how do senior police officers decide whether assembly constitutes a serious disruption? Chief Constable @BJH251 says "Senior police officers always consider with the need for balance in background" @HumanRightsCtte

Matt Parr continues: "The law isn't a panacea, either." Many recommendations by @HMICFRS for policing of protest weren't about the law, there were much wider recommendations than just changes in the law @HumanRightsCtte

Of course there is a balance, but should cost to public purse be one of those considerations? Matt Parr @HMICFRS "absolutely not but protesting is an issue for the police and getting bigger" @HumanRightsCtte

Should we really be counting the cost of protest and deciding its too expensive? Matt Parr of @HMICFRS "Nobody disputes the fundamental right to protest, but my point is that those rights are not unfettered, they have to be exercised with other people's rights" @HumanRightsCtte

On next panel, Chief Constable @BJH251 tells @HumanRightsCtte "We have powers that we use sparingly, but there is need to modernise those powers to make sure they're clear and current and to allow us to balance rights between those who wish to assemble, and those affected by it"

.@Jules_Carey agrees. "There is an alarming increase in penalties that are wholly disproportionate in the Police Bill. Significantly more draconian powers relating to protest and taken together, all the new offences will have a chilling effect on people taking part in protest"
"The real serious harm that needs to be focused on is the serious harm that protest movements are seeking to expose, and these types of sentences are egregious and disproportionate" @zedhas3

.@zedhas3 of @blkprotestlegal on 10 year sentencing for "public nuisance" @HumanRightsCtte - "It is clearly egregiously excessive. Protests are liable to be a nuisance and tiresome, the fundamental principle of protest is to cause disruption."

.@Jules_Carey summarises to @HumanRightsCtte "When you take all of the Police Bill provisions together, they clearly violate international human rights standards and constitute a savage attack on the right to peaceful assembly"

"The Govt's attempt to roll out new approaches to protest, along with authoritarian Police Bill, is going to further embed systemic racism into the policing of protest and will sharply affect our communities" @zedhas3 from @blkprotestlegal tells @HumanRightsCtte

"The Police Bill is entirely adverse to the requirement for state to positively facilitate right to protest. And if we have the broad provisions of Police Bill, black and brown protestors will be the ones most affected" @zedhas3 tells @HumanRightsCtte

"All of the effective protests in the past have caused some form of disruption. There's a broad range of people who should be concerned about this Police Bill if it goes through" Kevin Blowe of @netpol tells @HumanRightsCtte

.@zedhas3 of @blkprotestlegal expands: Creating noise at a protest is literally people making their voices heard. Trying to curtail every aspect of civil disobedience, the Police Bill is trying to restrict our right to protest. @HumanRightsCtte

.@Jules_Carey continues: "Art 11.2 of ECHR sets out clearly the permitted limitations that may be imposed on right to protest. It would be impossible to consider that unease would fall within those permitted restrictions" @HumanRightsCtte
"To consider placing a ban on protest because it causes unease or discomfort is inherently contradictory to the point of a protest." @Jules_Carey to @HumanRightsCtte

.@Jules_Carey This new trigger, which is "noise", is an absolute affront to the right to protest. It is an existential threat to the right to protest. Protests should be heard and seen and are pointless otherwise @HumanRightsCtte
In Police Bill, are terms "serious unease, alarm or distress" sufficiently clear for protest organisers or protestors to predict? @HumanRightsCtte

.@Jules_Carey One of the concerns I would have about this Bill is that the Home Sec has reserved for herself the right to define serious disruption. There are a number of problems with that - lack of parl scrutiny, a blanket approach not suitable @HumanRightsCtte

.@zedhas3 "This issue of serious disruption goes to the very heart of what it means to protest. Protest as a tool of mass resistance has often been used to bring about social change." @HumanRightsCtte
"Decisions about what constitutes serious disruption are often vague and are often very political" Kevin Blowe of @netpol tells @HumanRightsCtte talking about the policing of protests

.@Jules_Carey highlights what is missing in the Bill - "The kind of language showing importance of protest is dramatically absent from this Bill. The Bill is about managing protest and muting voices of dissent" @HumanRightsCtte

Should there be a statutory right to demonstrate put in the Bill? @zedhas3 of @blkprotestlegal, having a right to protest in this Bill would be meaningless given the contradictory laws contained in the Bill. @HumanRightsCtte

.@netpol coordinator says one of things missing is a statutory obligation on part of National Police Chiefs Council to give clear Human Rights guidelines to individual forces on how they conduct ops that are HR-compliant. @HumanRightsCtte

.@zedhas3 says the police are already using their powers to stifle protest, and have been emboldened to do so by Covid laws. "The perception that the police are using any of these powers in a fair and effective way is illusory" @HumanRightsCtte

.@HumanRightsCtte is hearing evidence about the Gov Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill. @Jules_Carey starts by saying: I would say categorically that the police do have enough powers. Not just me saying that, but the police say that too.

What do you see as the ongoing challenges for protecting human rights of care home residents in coming years? Minister @Helen_Whately: I want us to come out of pandemic with a stronger system. E.g. we have developed a greater system of oversight @HumanRightsCtte

Roughly when might we see an easing on restrictions on visiting out for care home residents? @ejomoore we have the ambition to enable more activities to happen from May onwards. Minister @Helen_Whately is keen that we enable this quickly. @HumanRightsCtte
@ejomoore also pays testament to all those people working in care homes to protect residents. "Heroic in the truest sense of the word". @HumanRightsCtte

Our ambition is to have more people visiting in and out, and to have that done safely. This is a really important issue and we are very conscious of the harm and impact that isolation has had on people in care homes. @ejomoore to @HumanRightsCtte

(contd) @ejomoore but we are currently consulting to see if there are ways that we could appropriately delineate activities that would not need isolation for 14 days afterwards, and the Minister has been pushing us to work quickly on this @HumanRightsCtte

(contd) @ejomoore: The thinking behind the guidance is to protect vulnerable people from covid outbreaks. Some activities outside are low risk, but it is difficult to define this and protect vulnerable settings and people. @HumanRightsCtte

Gov guidance says that a resident should isolate for 14 days upon returning to a home, making external visits difficult. When Gov next reviews guidance, will it look at this? Minister @Helen_Whately I absolutely appreciate importance of ability to leave a home.
So they could start with a general policy, but then they would still have to do an individualised risk assessment within that? Minister: yes. @HumanRightsCtte

Given the guidance for individualised risk assessments, do you agree that all blanket visiting policies undermine the guidance? Minister @Helen_Whately I would expect homes to make exceptions from a general policy based on needs of a resident @HumanRightsCtte

Minister @Helen_Whately: We are watching closely on how our latest guidance is implemented, working to identify gap between guidance and practice. If we don't see visiting open up in line with current guidance, I keep an open mind on how to ensure people have the right to visit

Is care home guidance "a framework to aspire to?" Minister @Helen_Whately to @HumanRightsCtte: It is very carefully thought through guidance on what is safe and balances the importance of visiting with covid risk. So we would expect care homes to follow that guidance.

Completely understand concerns around administrative burdens. But couldn't @DHSCgovuk take a sample? @Helen_Whately: we have regional assurance team, @CareQualityComm effectively works on samples, and our testing team will be able to contact homes about use of tests for visitors

Minister @Helen_Whately continues: We have created a regional assurance team, and are only hearing of a small handful of care homes that aren't supporting visits, and even that is usually when there is an outbreak. @HumanRightsCtte

.@dean4watford @HumanRightsCtte would you agree that it would be useful to have basic numbers for care home visits, so you could track activity? @Helen_Whately I would like that, but we have around 15,000 homes, and data can require a substantial amount of work for providers

Lord Henley asks "What would you say to families who believe quality of life at end of life is what matters?" Minister @Helen_Whately: I understand the importance of visits, throughout the pandemic we've said that visits towards end of life should be supported @HumanRightsCtte
"We have sought to achieve exactly that balance, whilst I wouldn't suggest it was an easy balance to strike" @DHSCgovuk minister @Helen_Whately to @HumanRightsCtte

Committee asks Minister @Helen_Whately: has the Government got its approach right? "Our approach to visiting has been to try and reduce risk, whilst recognising that visiting is hugely valuable in its own right" @HumanRightsCtte

Do you recognise worry of families who report information about the quality of care in homes? 
Peter Wyman: I fully understand concerns. We always keep any information private and anonymous, and we never disclose to the home that we have received information. @HumanRightsCtte

But then what are you going to do about Care England who seem to disagree? Peter Wyman @CareQualityComm: the homes are clear about it too, so I don't think any reasonable reason for people to see guidance as optional. @HumanRightsCtte

Do you think Gov guidance is advice, or to be complied with? Peter Wyman @CareQualityComm "We agree with you completely on this, we expect guidance from the Government to be complied with" @HumanRightsCtte

.@KateTerroni tells the @HumanRightsCtte "we've heard loud and clear from residents and families that visiting is happening, but it is a very different type of visiting" with time slots, restricted locations, and is in no way ideal for care home residents and families.

Peter Wyman acknowledges @CareQualityComm didn't see it useful to compile quantitative data across the sector but confident they have a good grasp of the sector through reporting and inspections, and are able to make sure that people can visit loved ones safely @HumanRightsCtte

@dean4watford: if you don't have data on visits, how can you be sure that visits are being allowed? Peter Wyman: We constantly monitor providers and receive information from relatives and inspectors. We take a qualitative view of whether provision is appropriate @HumanRightsCtte
"We regard the Government advice as something we expect homes to follow. We expect Government guidelines to be adhered to" Peter Wyman to @HumanRightsCtte

@dean4watford asks why it wasn't possible previously to provide information about how many homes are complying with guidance. Peter Wyman @CareQualityComm says that today they are not aware of any homes not complying with right to visits. @HumanRightsCtte

Are you satisfied with how @CareQualityComm has defended the rights of residents and families? Peter Wyman: I can honestly say that we have been taking action so that as far as possible visiting can take place, but obviously there are restrictions @HumanRightsCtte

First question @JCHR to Peter Wyman and @KateTerroni  @CareQualityComm: How have you inspected and monitored services to ensure respect for right to family life? @KateTerroni says CQC have enhanced their efforts to hear from providers, w/ 18,500 monitoring conversations

.@HelenMountfield rounds up to @HumanRightsCtte "If we had been able to be proud of the #HRAct in the way that we are of the NHS there wouldn't be a question of doing with it or seeing it as a plot. It just isn't. It should be seen as a universal thing and it is sad that it isn't

Richard Hermer QC: Seeing the reaction of Iraqis to being able to have their case heard, I found that a deeply patriotic moment because it vindicated the rule of law. It is a human element of what the #HRAct is capable of bringing @HumanRightsCtte

Richard Hermer QC tells @HumanRightsCtte that whereas the #HRAct provides the mechanism to show that UK has properly investigated conduct British troops, without it those soldiers are placed at risk of being dragged to the International Criminal Court. "That is of great concern"

Is there case for limiting rights of individuals to have cases determined by UK Courts? @HelenMountfield: If state power is exercised, even abroad, it makes sense for legal remedy to be the same wherever state power exercised @HumanRightsCtte
Richard Hermer QC makes the point to @HumanRightsCtte that "We should never lose sight of the fact that these aren't just human rights, but also British values"

.@HelenMountfield makes the point: "Which one of these rights do we not want to have? What is wrong with any of the rights? It is important that we argue for these as fundamental human entitlements" @HumanRightsCtte

Richard Hermer QC: My general point is "if it ain't broke don't fix it" - you risk having unintended consequences and in the consequence of an Act as important as the #HRAct, that has real consequences. @HumanRightsCtte

.@HelenMountfield suggests that a small but important change is that when a declaration of incompatibility is made, when a remedial order is put before parlt. it has option to say yes or no, or place amendments. would increase parliamentary input on legislation @HumanRightsCtte

Are there any reforms of #HRAct you would like to see?

@GDSGee: Could make an argument to amend Section 2 to provide some direction that the court should not go beyond Strasbourg case law. @HumanRightsCtte

.@HelenMountfield "The fiction that pre-#HRAct the law was maths and there was nothing for judges to do, is just not true. The #HRAct has enabled people to articulate their rights and made the law more accessible, and that's a good thing for effective govt." @HumanRightsCtte

Prof @GDSGee to @HumanRightsCtte "There is a case to be made that the #HRAct compromises the rule of law in a number of ways, by introducing into dom. law convention rights that are framed w/ greater degree of uncertainty"

So what would be the point in taking HR claim to court? @JoshuaRozenberg: there would still be challenges, but it would be much easier for the Govt. if e.g. they didn't have to pay compensation to people who had had benefits wrongly withheld in the past @HumanRightsCtte

What impact would that have in terms of the workings of the #HRAct? @JoshuaRozenberg in one sense it would make things very orderly, but it another sense people who win their cases wouldn't receive any benefits  @HumanRightsCtte

.@JoshuaRozenberg to @HumanRightsCtte "in another context, the Govt. is considering a presumption that remedies will be prospective only. It occurs to me that Govt. might be considering changing the remedies that are available under a successful HRs claim"

Prof @GDSGee provides @HumanRightsCtte with eg of the use of Sec3 of #HRAct when interpreting Sec41 of YJCE Act 1999 - courts used Sec3 to upend parliamentary policy choice in a way not consistent with legal certainty

.@JoshuaRozenberg: "if the #HRAct had not been enacted, the judges would be using the common law in the same way. The judges are always developing the law, and the use whatever tools that allow them to do that" @HumanRightsCtte
.@HelenMountfield to @HumanRightsCtte "I don't agree that judges think they can, or do in fact, use Sec 3 of #HRAct as an instrument of practical law reform, as @GDSGee puts it"

Prof. @GDSGee notes his concern about the extent to which the #HRAct might warp the operation of other important constitutional principles e.g. effect of Section 3 potentially obscuring the distinction between the judicial and legislative function @HumanRightsCtte
.@HelenMountfield tells @HumanRightsCtte "I just don't understand how it can be said that the #HRAct is a constraint on parlt. sovereignty - because it is a vindication of it"

Richard Hermer QC @matrixchambers expands @HumanRightsCtte: the #HRAct has had an incredibly positive effect. As a clear articulation of rights, it creates a culture where people talk about those rights, & meant judges and politicians are more conversant w/ HRs

What was the impact of #HumanRightsAct on enforcement of HRs? @JoshuaRozenberg to @HumanRightsCtte: "The impact was huge." People no longer need to take the UK Govt to Strasbourg in order to enforce your HRs. It made access to justice faster and cheaper

What are main HR issues facing the UK coming out of pandemic? @HumanRightsCtte 

Chair @ScotHumanRights: People's economic and social rights. Pandemic affects poorest people hardest

Chair @NIHRC: inequalities have been highlighted by pandemic, both BAME and income inequality.

On gender pay gap reporting during pandemic: @EHRCChair: "I don't accept that there are very good reasons for companies not to report by April, but we've given them a little bit more time until October. We will use the added time to analyse the data" @HumanRightsCtte

Chair @ScotHumanRights: "I've seen the population of UK uphold the rights of other citizens by complying with lockdown. They understood that rights of older & vulnerable people are paramount. We should draw strength from that" @HumanRightsCtte

On impact of covid on HRs: 

Chair @NIHRC: "its sharpened understanding that you can't take rights for granted"

Chair @ScotHumanRights:"I've seen the debate around HRs really strengthen and grow, the quality and understanding of civil society has been boosted" @HumanRightsCtte

Both Chairs @NIHRC and @ScotHumanRights highlight importance that any amendments to #HRAct pay careful attention to implications they may have on the Union and the Northern Ireland Agreement @HumanRightsCtte
Chair of @NIHRC: "Its about the only submission in my 7 years where we have said there is no need for change. We couldn't see what the problems were that needed to be fixed" @HumanRightsCtte
Chair of @ScotHumanRights "It is unusual for us not to make recommendations of changes to legislation, but in this case we recommended no changes" @HumanRightsCtte
Chair of @EHRC Baroness Falkner confirms: "I really cannot see that we need amendments to the Act at this time. I wouldn't reopen it."
Chair of @NIHRC summarises to @HumanRightsCtte his experience in NI: "The idea that somehow we're being ruled by courts and court decisions seems to me a long way off the mark"

Chair @ScotHumanRights continues: "that's not to say that Govts are going to like everything that the court says. But  that is not a good enough reason to weaken the legislation - in fact it is a good reason NOT to do it" @HumanRightsCtte

Judith Robertson, Chair of @ScotHumanRights "the judiciary is playing a role of independent oversight... the #HRAct is a clever piece of legislation, it is held internationally as being so, its well-constructed to respect the rights of parliament" @HumanRightsCtte

Do you think that the #HRAct draws courts into making decisions on things that are better decided on by Parliament? Is that a problem? 
@EHRCChair Baroness Falkner: No I don't think that's a problem.  @HumanRightsCtte

Chair of @NIHRC @LesAllamby: "I'm  struck by assumption that judicial dialogue between UK and Strasbourg impairs UK's sovereignty. Clear UK courts not in thrall to Strasbourg judgments, but they do have to take into account. They do by and large w/out difficulty"@HumanRightsCtte

Chair of @NIHRC is very clear: "If we were to move away and dilute significantly the machinery of the #HRAct, that to me seems counterintuitive to the clear aim of the Good Friday Agreement. I really would caution against that" @HumanRightsCtte

On the importance of #HRAct to Good Friday Agreement @LesAllamby tells @HumanRightsCtte : "It is clear under the 1998 Agreement that the importance was not just incorporating HR into domestic law, but also having meaningful remedies"

@EHRCChair Baroness Falkner adds that "under our current powers we can't go there, but there is a way to work across regulators, with the Care Quality Commission. We're looking at it actively to see who does what next"

Chair of @NIHRC on care home visits: "we're limited in that we can hold an investigation but the time it would take would cause difficulties". "Its clear that blanket bans are unacceptable but beyond that trying to discern what is going on is very difficult" @HumanRightsCtte

What about enforcement of the right to family life? @EHRC and @ScotHumanRights confirm they are active in calling for the right to visits but not currently in a position to back enforcement @HumanRightsCtte
Does the @EHRC think the right to care home visits for families should be enshrined in Regulations, not just guidance? Yes, says @KishwerFalkner to @HumanRightsCtte
Chair of @NIHRC @LesAllamby says the #HRAct has led to an "embedding of a culture of rights", and that Human Rights were at the centre of the Belfast Good Friday Agreement
Baroness Falkner @EHRCChair tells @HumanRightsCtte that the #HRAct has "domesticised Human Rights", giving UK citizens a direct route for redress rather than having to go to Strasbourg

It has been clear for some time that blanket bans on care home visits will not be stopped by Guidance. Need it in law. @HumanRightsCtte has drafted Regulations. Govt must bring in now @rightsforresid2 @BBCr4today

"In order to protect my colleagues and the public, I do feel that in the height of the pandemic there should have been more restrictions on protest, as difficult a message as that is" @PFEW_Chair to @HumanRightsCtte #covid19

"Our relation with the public is so important. But every time the legislation changes, officers need to interpret with no time at all. 9 out of 10 officers felt that regulations were not clear" @PFEW_Chair to @HumanRightsCtte

"Overwhelmingly when people have regs explained they comply with the guidance of officers... There is evidence that officers are using their discretion to warn and advise people in the interest of their public health" @BJH251 to @HumanRightsCtte

Similar figures from @BJH251 to @HumanRightsCtte for Essex police force, 37,000 engagements with members of public and only 929 resulted in Fixed Penalty Notice. "We have worked to warn, encourage and explain to people"

Owen Weatherill gives evidence to @HumanRightsCtte that British Transport Police have had over 74,000 interactions on #covid19 matters, only 173 resulted in tickets. "The no. of tickets is very small proportion"
@Kirsty_Brimelow gives evidence to @HumanRightsCtte on Fixed Penalty Notices: "they do engage Human Rights issues, and potentially they are breaching those HRs" #covid19

@graciemaybe @libertyhq  talks to @HumanRightsCtte about the "four E's" for policing: "they are good in principle but unevenly used in practice. They failed to deal with gap between guidance and the law"
@Kirsty_Brimelow gives @HumanRightsCtte an initial view on Fixed Penalty Notices: "they do engage Human Rights, and potentially and on occasions they are breaching those Human Rights"
